name: GitHub
title: GitHub
description: How to integrate GitHub with Make.com

children.text: GitHub is a platform for hosting and collaborating on code repositories. Integrating GitHub with Make.com allows users to automate repository management, issue tracking, and pull request workflows directly from their GitHub accounts.
This is AI-generated content based on official GitHub documentation. The content may contain mistakes. Please verify important information. If you have questions on vendor documentation, contact
To use the GitHub app in Make,
you must have an active GitHub account and appropriate authentication credentials such as a personal access token or GitHub App token,
To get started, you must first create a connection between GitHub and
, allowing the two services to communicate.
Obtain your API Key in your GitHub account
Obtain your API Key in your GitHub account
Before you create the connection in
Click your profile picture in the upper-right corner.
Enter a name for your token.
Select an expiration date for your token.
Select the permissions or scopes required for your use case.
Copy the API token displayed on screen.
You will use this value while creating a connection in
Because the UI might have changed, the steps you see on your screen might be different,
check the vendor documentation for updates.
, add the GitHub module to your
If you add a module with an instant tag, click
field, enter a name for the connection.
you copied from your GitHub account or follow the on-screen instructions to create the connection.
For detailed information on connecting an application, see
After connecting to the GitHub app, you can choose from a list of available modules to build your
Assigns one or more users to a specific issue or pull request.
Applies one or more labels to a selected issue or pull request.
Adds a new comment to a specified item or record.
Creates a new commit in the specified repository.
Creates a new issue in the selected project or repository.
Removes selected assignees from a specified issue or pull request.
Deletes a specified comment from the selected item.
Removes a specified label from a selected issue.
Deletes a specified issue from your project.
Executes a custom GraphQL query with authorization.
Fetches details of a specified existing branch.
Fetches the details of a specific existing comment by its identifier.
Fetches and downloads a specific file using its unique ID.
Fetches the details of a specified existing gist from your account.
Fetches the details of a specific milestone that already exists.
Fetches the details of a specific pull request from your repository.
Fetches the details of a specific existing release.
Fetches detailed information about a specified existing repository.
Fetches detailed information about a specific existing user.
Retrieves detailed information about a specified assignee.
Fetches the details of a specific existing issue from your account.
Fetches detailed information about a specified organization.
Searches for specific assignees or retrieves a complete list of all assignees.
Searches for specific branches or retrieves a list of all branches in the repository.
Searches for specific comments or retrieves a complete list of all comments.
Searches for specific gists or retrieves a complete list of all available gists.
Searches for specific issues or retrieves a complete list of all issues.
Searches for specific milestones or retrieves a complete list of all milestones.
Searches for specific members within an organization or retrieves a complete list of all organization members.
Searches for specific pull requests or retrieves a list of all pull requests in a repository.
Searches for specific releases or retrieves a complete list of all available releases.
Modifies the content of an existing comment.
Modifies the details of an existing issue.
Uploads a specified file to the selected repository.
Triggers when a new branch is created in your repository.
Triggers when a new comment is added to a specific commit in your repository.
Triggers when a new commit is added to a repository.
Triggers when a user creates a new fork of a repository.
Triggers when a new GitHub Gist is created or an existing Gist is updated.
Triggers whenever a new issue is created or an existing issue is updated in your project.
Triggers when a new label is added to your account.
Triggers when a new milestone is added or an existing milestone is modified in your project.
Triggers when a new organization record is added to your account.
Triggers when a new pull request is opened or an existing pull request is modified in your repository.
Triggers when a new software release is published in your repository.
Triggers when a new repository is created in your connected account.

, where you'll find thousands of pre-created

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
